quiz.text: If K litres of the mixture from vessel R is poured into vessel P, such that milk in the vessel becomes 20% more than that of water, while rest of the mixture from vessel R is poured into vessel Q, such that the ratio of milk and water in vessel Q becomes 69:37 respectively. Find M is approximately how much percentage of (M + N).
options: 78%
81%
80%
77%
Can’t be determined

quiz.text: A milkman has a mixture of milk and water in the same ratio as that of the final mixture in vessel Q, and has the same amount (with respect to Q1). He sold L ml of mixture to a customer and then added 55 ml milk and 15 ml water, so the amount of milk in mixture becomes twice of water. Find the value of L?
options: 636 ml
424 ml
530 ml
630 ml
None of these

quiz.text: A milkman has 300 liters of a mixture of milk and water, in which milk is 50% of the numerical value of the amount of milk added to vessel P from vessel R (with respect to Q1). He sold 60 liters of the mixture to the first customer, and then added the same amount of water. Then, he sold a 75 liters mixture to a second customer and then added the same amount of water. Then he sold 40% of the mixture to the customer and then added water which is equivalent to 40% of the mixture left. Find the concentration of pure milk in the mixture. (Approx.)
options: 25.92%
25.82%
30.85%
39.95%
None of these

quiz.text: If the total quantity of chemical C1 in container 1 is mixed with the total quantity of chemical C2 in container 2 and poured into container 3 to form a new adhesive. If 100 liters of adhesive Mixture is removed and replaced by the same quantity of chemical C2, then again 150 liters of Adhesive Mixture is removed and replaced by the same quantity of chemical C2. Now find the quantity of chemical C2 in container 3?
options: 328 liters
368 liters
362 liters
352 liters
Can’t be determined

quiz.text: Difference between the quantity of C1 and C2 in adhesive 1 is approximately how much percentage of the quantity of C2 in adhesive 3?
options: 217%
220%
215%
216%
222%

quiz.text: In each of the following questions three or more statements are given. You are expected to decide which of the following statements or pair of statements is sufficient to answer the question. A mixture of milk and water of 120 liters, in which water is 40 ml. If ___ liters of mixture are replaced by water, then _____ liters of mixture are replaced by water. Now the amount of water in the final mixture is ______ liters. Find which of the following statements is/are satisfied with the blanks in the same order. I. 24, 60, 88 II. 30, 48, 84 III. 66, 20, 80 IV.12, 15, 57
options: I, II, and III only
I, II, and IV only
I and IV only
II, III, IV only
None of these

quiz.text: P liters mixture of milk and water, where milk is twice as that of water. If Q liters of water are added to the mixture, then water becomes 75% of milk. If 3.5Q liters of mixture is removed and replaced by 2Q liters of milk, then quantity of milk in mixture can be ________ liters I. 4Q II. 6Q III. 2P/3
options: I only
II only
III only
I and III only
II and III only

quiz.text: A vessel contains mixture of milk and water in which milk is _____ liters and water is 80 liters. If 40% of mixture is taken out in a container and then add 28 liters of water in container, then ratio of milk and water in the container is _______. The value given in which of the following options will fill the blanks in the same order in which is it given to make the above statement true: I. 200, 4:3 II. 150, 1:1 III. 160, 15:16
options: I only
I and II only
II and III only
All are true
None of these

quiz.text: There are three varieties of salt with their quantity in the ratio of 3 : 4 : 5. If ____kg of first variety and ____kg of second variety are added to their respective quantity and x kg of third type is removed from it, then the final ratio becomes 9 : 10 : 10. Then the sum of the initial quantities of these varieties is ____kg. The value given in which of the following options will fill the blanks in the same order in which it is given to make the statement true. I). 9, 4, 108 II). 15, 12, 84 III). 9, 2, 144
options: Only I
Only III
Only I and II
All I, II and III
Only II and III

quiz.text: In mixture P of milk and water, difference between quantity of milk and water is ____ L. Mixture Q contains milk and water in the ratio 4: 9 and mixtures P and Q are mixed together in the ratio 8: 13 to form mixture R that contains milk and water in the ratio 3: 4. Sum quantity of milk and water in mixture P is ____ L. Which of the following value will fill the blanks given in the question in the same order? A: 20 and 80 B: 45 and 180 C: 30 and 100
options: Only B and C
Only A and C
Only A
Only A and B
All A, B and C

quiz.text: A vessel contains R liters mixture of milk and water in which amount of water is twice as that of milk. If P liters of mixture is removed and replaced by Q liters of Milk then ratio of milk to water in final mixture becomes 5:2, while quantity of mixture becomes 210 liters. If P is 25% less than that of Q than find which of the following is/are not the possible value of R. I. 150% of Q II. 2P III. 6(P – Q) IV. P/2 + Q/3 + 85
options: I and II only
I, II and III only
IV only
I and IV only
None of these

quiz.text: There are four containers [A, B, C and D]. Each container has a different amount of milk and mixture. Find the difference between the total amount of mixture in container A and container C. I. Amount of milk in container A is 40 Liters. Milk in container B is equal to the amount of water in container C. Ratio of milk and water in container C is 5:6. II. Ratio of milk and water in container B is 6:7. The amount of water in container A is equal to the amount of milk in container C. III. Ratio of milk and water in A is 8:5. The amount of water in container A is equal to the amount of milk in container C. IV. Total amount of mixture in D is 80 Litres which is 15 Litres more than the total amount of mixture in container B.
options: Only I & III are sufficient
Only II is sufficient
Only III is sufficient
both I & II are sufficient
only I & IV are sufficient

quiz.text: A mixture of milk and water, milk is 150% of water. If K litres of mixture is removed and then Y litres of water added so the ratio of milk and water becomes 6:7 and final quantity of Mixture becomes 104 litres. If the ratio of K and Y is 5:3 and initial quantity mixture is L litres. Which of the following is not the value of ‘L’? I). 750% of difference between value of K and Y II).25% more than sum of value of Y and initial quantity of milk III). 20 less than 125% of final quantity of mixture
options: I only
III only
II and III only
I and III only
All of the above

quiz.text: In mixture A ratio of salt to sugar is 3: 2 and in mixture B ratio of salt to sugar is 5: 3. If both the mixtures are mixed together to form a new mixture, then find the quantity of salt in the new mixture? I: Quantities of sugar in mixtures A and B are equal and difference between the quantities of salt and sugar in the final mixture is 35 kg. II: Quantity of salt in mixture B is 5 kg more than that in mixture A and ratio of salt in mixture A to that in mixture B is 9: 10.
options: Statement I alone is sufficient to answer the question but the statement II alone is not sufficient
Statement II alone is sufficient to answer the question but the statement I alone is not sufficient.
Both statements I and II together are needed to answer the question.
Either statement I alone or statement II alone is sufficient to answer the question.
Both the statements together are not sufficient to answer the question.

quiz.text: (3.5K + 10) litres of Mixture X contains milk and water and (2.5K – 18.5) litres of Mixture Y contains water and honey. A trader mixes 45% of mixture X with some quantity of mixture Y, now find amount of water in final mixture is what % more than amount of honey in final mixture. Statement I: Ratio of amount of milk and water in mixture X is 3:2 and water in mixture X is 18.5 litres more than water in mixture Y. Statement II:  Water in mixture Y is 25% less than honey and difference between amount of Milk and Honey in final mixture is 6.3 litres.
options: Statement I alone is sufficient to answer the question but Statement II alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
Statement II alone is sufficient to answer the question but Statement I alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
Either statement I or II alone is sufficient to answer the question
Both the statements taken together are necessary to answer the question, but neither of the statement alone is sufficient to answer the question.
Both statement I and II together are not sufficient to answer the question.

quiz.text: P = There are three vessels M, N, and L. M contains milk and water in a ratio of 5:3, L contains milk and water in 2:1, while N contains pure water. A new mixture is formed by taking 48 ml from vessel M, (2K - 74) ml from vessel N and 36 ml from vessel L, such that milk in the new mixture is 50% more than water. Find the value of K in ml. Q = A vessel contains a mixture of milk and water in which milk is 50% more than water. If 25 ml mixture is removed and replaced by water, then water becomes 22.22% more than milk. Find the amount of water in the vessel initially.
options: P > Q
P < Q
P = Q
P ≤ Q
P ≥ Q

quiz.text: An 80 Litres mixture contains different quantities of liquid A and liquid B. Per litre cost of liquid B is 50% of that of liquid A. Cost of the mixture is Rs.39 per Litres, which is Rs.9 per Litres less than that of liquid A. Quantity I: Find the percentage of liquid B in the mixture. Quantity II: Find the difference between per litre costs of liquid A and liquid B. Quantity III: If the mixture is sold at 33(1/3) % loss, then find the selling price of the mixture. If Quantity I ___ Quantity II ___ Quantity III, then which of the following symbols can be filled in the blanks respectively.
options: >, <
>, =
<, <
=, <
<, >

quiz.text: Vessels X and Y contain a mixture of two liquids P and Q in a ratio of 4:1 and 7:3 respectively. Mixtures in vessel X and Vessel Y are mixed to form a new mixture R. Quantity I: find the quantity of mixture R, if X and Y mixed in 3:2 ratio and difference between quantity of P and of Q in mixture R is 1040 ml. Quantity II: Find 34% quantity of mixture R, on selling mixture R at cost price of liquid P, there is profit of 66.66% (Rs. 2000). Cost price of liquid P is Rs. 800 per litre.
options: Quantity I > Quantity II
Quantity I < Quantity II
Quantity I = Quantity II or No relation
Quantity I ≥ Quantity II
Quantity I ≤ Quantity II

quiz.text: There are three mixtures A, B and C of water and milk. The ratio of milk to water in Mixture A is 2 : 3. The ratio of milk to water in Mixture B is 2 : 1. The ratio of milk to water in Mixture C is 3 : 4. When 20% of Mixture A and 25% of Mixture B is mixed the percentage of milk in the resultant mixture becomes 56%. When 25% of Mixture A and 75% of Mixture C is mixed the water in the resultant mixture becomes 15/26. Quantity I: What is the quantity of Mixture A? Quantity II: What is the quantity of Mixture B? Quantity III: What is the quantity of Mixture C?
options: Quantity I > Quantity II > Quantity III
Quantity I < Quantity II < Quantity III
Quantity I > Quantity II < Quantity III
Quantity I = Quantity II > Quantity III
Quantity I > Quantity II = Quantity III

quiz.text: Quantity I: In a mixture, with milk and water in the ratio 9: 2, 4 liter of milk and 2 lit of water is added making the ratio of milk and water 4: 1. What was the difference between the quantity of milk and water in the initial quantity? Quantity II: A mixture has milk and water in the ratio 9: 5. In the mixture, 8 lit of milk and 8 lit of water is added making the ratio of milk and water 5: 3. What is the difference between the quantity of milk and water in the final mixture?
options: Quantity: I > Quantity: II
Quantity: I ≥ Quantity: II
Quantity: I < Quantity: II
Quantity: II ≥ Quantity: I
Quantity I = Quantity II or relation can't be established

quiz.text: The cost of type A oil is Rs.80/L and that of type B oil is Rs.60/L. A container contains a certain quantity of type A oil. From this container some quantity of type A oil is taken out and replaced with type B oil and this process is repeated 1 more time. If in the final mixture type A oil is 74.4 L more than type B oil and cost of the mixture is Rs.76.2/L, then find that what per cent of type A oil was replaced.
options: 15%
21%
19%
17%
23%

quiz.text: A jar had 330-liter mixture of Milk and water in the respective ratio of 2 : 1.60 liters of this mixture is taken out and ‘x’ liter each of milk and water is added to the jar (remaining mixture). The respective ratio between milk and water was 8 :5 respectively. What was the total quantity of both milk and water added to the jar?
options: 60 liter
180 liter
120 liter
100 liter
150 liter

quiz.text: In mixture A, quantity of milk is 10 L more than that of water and in mixture B, quantity of Milk is 20 L more than that of water. When both the mixtures are mixed together, quantity of water becomes 62.5% of that of milk in the final mixture. Find the total quantity of final mixture?
options: 120 L
110 L
130 L
150 L
140 L

quiz.text: A shopkeeper mixed Banana Juice and pomegranate Juice in the ratio of 4:5. Now he removed 45 litres of mixture and then added 190 litres of another mixture in which the ratio of Banana Juice and pomegranate Juice is 23:15. The ratio of Banana juice and pomegranate juice in the new mixture becomes 167:140. Find 37.5% of the quantity of Banana juice in initial mixture?
options: 27 litres
36 litres
48 litres
24 litres
None of these

quiz.text: A milkman has 960 litres of pure milk. He gives 240 litres of milk to first customer and then adds same amount of water. After that, he gives 240 litres of mixture to second customer and then adds same amount of water. He did the same process up to nth customer. Find the amount of pure milk given to 4th customer?
options: 303.75 liters
302.75 liters
101.75 liters
101.25 liters
204.75 liters
